Before I start I want to say something that honourable members on the other side of the House ought to learn from. Instead of just carping and whingeing all the time there are situations where a bit of credit ought to be paid where it is due. Three years ago in this House I raised a very strong complaint about the Woolworths supermarket organisation giving heavy promotion to overseas products and I said that it was encouraging Australian consumers to buy imported foodstuffs.

I am very pleased to report to the House that that organisation has changed its policy. I refer to an advertisement which was carried recently in daily newspapers in Victoria, encouraging the purchase of Australian-made products and stating that the company has now adopted a policy that Australian manufacturers, as they see it, employ many Australians who are Big W customers. Big W has also come to the conclusion that if one looks at the natural advantages of local manufacture, there is a 20 per cent price differential. So it has now adopted as a policy-I quote here from the words of the Chief General Manager, Mr Saunders-`If we can find an Australian manufacturer who shares our low margin philosphy and will work with us to deliver competitive prices to our customers, it's a much better deal all round'. So the company is committing itself to using Australian-made products.

I am very pleased to show you, Madam Speaker, also that it is now featuring the new green and gold kangaroo logo that this Government has endorsed with its Buy Australian true blue campaign. We are going to see this more and more in the shops of Australia. This is the genuine logo that verifies 70 per cent or more Australian content. I am very happy, Madam Speaker, to stand here in the House tonight and say that three years ago I was very critical of that company for its policy of promoting overseas imported foodstuffs. I am now very happy to give credit where credit is due and commend the Big W organisation for its revised philosophy on the purchase of Australian-made supplies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly I sat here in awe listening to the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) and his description of this excellent document, `Getting Australia Out of Debt', not knowing that paragraph 3 on page 6 does refer to an excellent initiative by the Opposition in working with the top rate for individuals, so that it is not higher than the company tax rate. But to think that someone of his standing would produce a tape recording to try to put the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in a poor light--
—Order! The honourable member has already apologised for that. He was unaware that he could not bring a tape recorder in.
—He has been here for seven years. That shows how stupid he is.
—Thank you. You are on our side.
—The honourable member for Gippsland will cease interjecting.

—I wish to highlight an issue that has been running around-certainly the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) made mention of it-and that is the postage entitlement for members of parliament. The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) initiated a statement that members on this side do not write to their constituents or do not work in their electorate. That is not the point. We do do that. That is a nice comment to make! On Canberra radio today the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) said that this was prompted by his very detailed analysis of the United States system and that people there get six stamp issues a year. But he said that he thought that Australians should get only four and that prompted the question `Minister, who initiated this? Where did the aggravation come from?', and he said, `Members of parliament'. When asked which members of parliament, he could not answer. He thought it was not part of the argument. My question today was going to be: who was the member of parliament, what party did he represent, and why was this extravagant increase-over 350 per cent-just granted by the stroke and the decree of the Executive arm of the Government? We will see whether it is legal.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—There is no point of order, Madam Speaker.
—Order! Would the honourable member for Adelaide resume his seat. The honourable member for Burke has a point of order.
—Madam Speaker, on a point of order: we did receive a memorandum on this topic from you.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.
—I am asking you a question, Madam Speaker. I wonder whether-if it is true that the United States people get six-you could seek six for us, too, please.
—The honourable member for Burke does not have a point of order. He will resume his seat. The honourable member for Gippsland will not attempt to make rulings in this House.
—Do I get an extension of time?
—You do not.

—Madam Speaker, this is a 350 per cent increase. The Government has lined the backbenchers and marginal seat holders of Australia with $413 a week and increased pensions by $2 a week. The Woolworths flyer that it has produced would buy a can of Pal. That $30,500 postal allowance is $5,000 more than average weekly earnings. It was stated that the allowance would allow mail to be sent out to about 70,000 people. There are basically 40,000 homes in the electorate. As a result of phone polling, Mr Cameron of Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd suggests that by targeting the 10,000 swinging voters-perhaps pensioners and youth-we can probably mail out about 7 1/2 times. That is what this is designed for. It is not designed so we can have just one mail-out to the electorate-to give us a warm inner glow in having one mail-out.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I was rudely interrupted by the honourable member for Burke I was suggesting that this proposal probably has been put together with some degree of illegality. I cannot believe that this allowance can be increased just by government decree. The Australian Labor Party is shifting its responsibility. It has already indicated in the House today that it intends to remove funding for television advertising, after promoting those glossy, full-paged newspaper and television advertisements for the family allowance supplement and the Department of Social Security-`Get a spare pair of Reeboks to make you look good'. Backdated to 1 July we are to get $30,000. No wonder there is indignation around the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You used to be in marketing. You should understand.
—I certainly am in marketing. This is one of the greatest rorts that you have perpetrated. To think that $30,000--

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Keefe interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, are you just going to let him waffle on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has a special way of celebrating battles. Anzac Day, one of our great national days, celebrates our loss in a battle in a war we eventually won. The celebration is not about winning or losing the battle but rather the performance of the soldiers-their courage, fortitude and, perhaps most of all, dignity. Newcastle and the Hunter Valley are currently engaged in what can be likened to a war. Unlike the First World War the battleground is the future and the enemy is intangible. Our community has watched with dismay the decline of the great industrial centres of the world such as Dusseldorf and Liverpool. We realise that unless we win this war their present will be our future.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently we have been involved in a tough and difficult contest in seeking to be the main centre for the construction of the Anzac light patrol frigate-a contest we worked hard and long to win. In the final analysis the consortium we supported, Australian Warships Systems (AWS), was unsuccessful. We are gracious enough to accept that, disappointed as we may be. To Melbourne and Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated we say, `Be sure your performance matches your promises because if it does not we will willingly do more of the work'. To the Government we say, `You have a ship at a very cheap price. Newcastle will be watching to ensure that that does not escalate. Be sure the contract is watertight'. To the community of Newcastle and the Hunter Valley, my community, I say, `You have fought with courage and dignity and it has been with pride that I have represented you. You have helped to show Australia that our region is united and committed to developing a future totally different from other centres. I also urge you to recognise that, like Gallipoli, this was but one battle, albeit it an important one in our longer term struggle. We must hold and consolidate the gains we have made if the future we want is to happen'. To the AWS consortium, the Dutch Government and the Dutch Navy I say, `Thank you for your confidence in us and for your assistance in uniting us. We have valued your friendship and we will do all we can to ensure it continues. You have, in Newcastle, a community that has confidence in you and your performance and it regrets that it will not be able to build the fine ship you offered'.

While I thank the wider community, there are some special people whose efforts must be noted in the records of this Parliament. These include Mr Terry Murray, a butcher who initiated the biggest petition in Newcastle's, and perhaps Australia's, history; his mates Col Russell, Jeff Pendlebury and Phil King in the Wallsend Plaza who helped produce and distribute the petitions; Paul Scott from the Newcastle Permanent Building Society, who did a special job of coordinating this massive effort; organisations including Shortland Electricity, NIB Health Funds Ltd, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales, the Metal Trades Industry Association, the trade union movement and local government; and the Hunter Development Board. They all contributed their energy, their goodwill and their commitment to our region. Dozens of others were united in this campaign in a way that has never happened before, but I am confident this will happen again and again in the future. I say to all of them `Thank you; I am proud of you, we owe you a great deal'. I also offer my sincere thanks to my parliamentary colleagues in the region who gave such strong support and back-up. Their efforts, while perhaps not widely recognised, were certainly crucial in our campaign. Madam Speaker, I make these remarks because I believe that Newscastle now has the kind of future which those people worked so hard to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ironically, the matter I wish to raise tonight also relates to the Hunter Valley. This week has been a very sad week for the Hunter Valley after the Cabinet decision of last Monday. I raise this matter in conjunction and in liaison with the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull). I do so because of a personal experience which needs to be placed on the record, given all that has now happened. I refer to the Whittingham Aerodrome which is located near Singleton and which is one of the most shocking, at times saturated and at times unsafe runways I have ever utilised in 18 years in parliament. So concerned was I, on Friday, 28 April, after taking off from this airstrip by commuter aircraft and flying to Sydney, that rather than have it on my conscience over the weekend I rang the airport inspection branch of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) in Sydney and suggested that it might like to inspect this runway.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have evidence that the CAA rang the operator of this particular aerodrome-a commuter airline company actually operates the Whittingham Aerodrome and maintains the runway-to warn it, inadvertently or otherwise, of the forthcoming inspection. The inspection did not in fact take place until Wednesday, 3 May. Interestingly enough, we now learn that there have been five inspections of this aerodrome. At this stage I do not criticise the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly), but she did advise me on 10 August that there have been no fewer than five inspections of this aerodrome, including the one on 3 May which I in part triggered because of the condition of this horrific runway, about which one pilot has asked: `Do we have to wait until bodies are lying on the runway to get action?'.

At long last the airport inspection branch has realised the seriousness of this matter. It has demanded that repairs which it identified in letters of 22 March and 7 June be carried out. In one of its letters it asks:
Have they now been completed? Repairs must be such as to withstand any recurrence after prolonged wet weather.
So it has taken until 14 August for the CAA to cover its tracks and make a direct approach to the operator to demand a proper standard and completion of repairs to the runway.

I am not prepared to have on my conscience the outcome of any horrific tragedy which could have occurred during winter months on that runway. I do not raise this matter lightly; it is a deadly serious matter. It is one that has also concerned the member for Upper Hunter, George Souris, MP, in the State Parliament. I am sorry that time has not permitted me to alert the Minister, but I have no argument with her at this stage of proceedings, other than to place on record my concerns. I demand that the Civil Aviation Authority become a lot more concerned about the state of that particular runway before an accident does occur. In particular, it should examine such things as the massive potholes on that runway which cause pilots to take swerving action in their take-offs and landings; the climb out to the western end of that runway; the use of the runway near dark during the winter months; and the trench which existed at the eastern end of the runway during much of April and May.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Australian Taxation Office (ATO) audit hours per hundred returns are devoted to (a) returns of high income compared with medium and low income earners and (b) company compared with individual income tax returns.
(2) How have the audit hours per hundred returns varied across these different groups since 1977.
(3) What is the return in additional tax collections per audit hour for (a) high income compared with low and medium income tax returns and (b) company compared with individual income tax returns.

(4) If the ATO cannot provide this kind of information, which is readily available from other tax authorities, including the US Internal Revenue Service, when will appropriate information systems be developed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) &(3) Australian Taxation Office (ATO) statistics are not available in the precise form requested. As might be expected the type and format of statistics kept have changed considerably in the last decade in line with the significant changes that have occurred within the ATO. Hence it is difficult to usefully compare figures available for 1986/87 and 1987/88 with limited information available for 1977.

It is notable that more recently there have been major strategic and structural changes within the audit area of the ATO. These changes have resulted in an increased emphasis on the larger taxpayers. In this regard, the Commissioner of Taxation has announced that the 100 largest corporate taxpayers will progressively be subject to ongoing and in-depth audit activity.

ATO audit activity covers all types of returns lodged-i.e. companies, trusts, partnerships and individuals. Following the recent move to self-assessment it has been necessary to establish an audit presence among salary and wage earners. That presence has been directed at generally supporting the move to self-assessment and, in particular, enforcing the new substantiation provisions of the income tax law.

In total terms the ATO devoted 21 and 15 direct audit hours per hundred taxpayers during 1986/87 and 1987/88 respectively. Direct audit hours per hundred business taxpayers for the two years for companies and individuals (including partners and beneficiaries) were 96, 99 and 41, 46 respectively.

Table 1 shows the number of direct audit hours per hundred business taxpayers for 1986/87 and 1987/88 within certain broad categories of total business receipts. The table also indicates the revenue per direct audit hour for each category.
Revenue is defined as tax and additional tax by way of penalty.

The apparent decrease in 1987/88 in the direct audit hours per 100 taxpayers is attributable to a substantial increase in the auditable population coupled with the impact of the major restructuring mentioned earlier. Table 2 provides details of these increases.

(4) The ATO is engaged on a major computer re-development and re-equipment program. Included among the uses planned for the system is the capacity for more comprehensive analysis and monitoring of audit activity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What studies support the statement made by the former Minister for Community Services on 31 March 1987 that successive reviews of the nursing home industry had, consistent with excessive industry regulations, produced an unacceptable escalation in costs and major inequities between States.
(2) Will he provide copies of those studies.
(3) Will he advise in specific and detailed terms, what changes have been made to overcome this problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(3) For more than a decade prior to 1986, majority criticisms were being voiced over many aspects of policy and program management in the aged care area and, in particular, residential care.

Specifically, there have been three major reports, the Auditor-General's Report on an efficiency audit of the Commonwealth administration of nursing home programs and two major reports to Parliament by Committees comprising representatives of both sides of politics. These are the Report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure: ``In a home or at home: accommodation and home care for the aged'' (McLeay Report) and a report by the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes: ``Private nursing homes in Australia: their conduct, administration and ownership'' (Giles Report).

All these reports were very critical of the Commonwealth's Residential Aged Program. In particular, the reports were critical of the inappropriate balance of services between nursing homes and hostels; the inappropriate mix between residential care and home and community care; the unplanned and unco-ordinated approach to residential care provision and the inefficient and inequitable funding arrangements that existed. The often inadequate quality of residential care, the need for more consistent inspection and better quality control arrangements and the crucial roles of assessment and rehabilitation were also highlighted in these reports.

The Nursing Homes and Hostels Review (1986), brought together the conclusions and recommendations of these previous reports and outlined a blueprint for a staged program of reform of residential care services for aged people. This Government acknowledged the validity of the criticisms that had been made over a number of years and decided to embark upon significant reforms.

These reforms, involving significant additional Commonwealth expenditure, will be carried out in eight stages. Stages 1 to 4 are already in place or being implemented. During the whole reform process extensive consultation has occurred, and will continue to take place, with State Governments and industry, consumer and employee groups.

As the first stage of the reform program, the Government made a significant commitment, in the 1986-87 Budget, to begin the process of redistribution resources for the care of aged people away from nursing homes to alternative less-institutionalised forms of residential care (such as hostels) and to community care services. Additional expenditure of approximately $24 million in 1986-87, $80 million in 1987-88 and $150 million in 1988-89 was announced at that time.

The main elements of this first stage included new needs-based planning arrangements linked to capital funding decisions for both nursing homes and hostels; the creation of Aged Care Advisory Committees to advise the Minister on the provision of new services; greater emphasis on increased numbers of hostel places through an expanded capital program; increased resources for home and community care; the development of co-ordinated assessment processes, including the staged establishment and expansion of assessment teams, to assist aged people and their families to plan the most appropriate care to meet their particular needs.

On 31 March 1987, the Government announced the second stage of the Government's program of reform involving some changes to nursing home funding arrangements as well as the introduction of quality of life and care standards in nursing homes. Increases in the level of recurrent funding for hostels were also announced at that time. On 21 April 1988, I announced the fourth stage of the program which introduced the remaining changes to the nursing home funding arrangements.

These new funding arrangements for non-Government nursing homes, catering exclusively or predominantly for the aged, are being phased in over the period 1 July 1987 to 1 July 1991. Under these arrangements, a national uniform funding system will replace the previous inefficient and inequitable cost reimbursement arrangements with:
a Standard Aggregated Module (SAM), introduced from 1 July 1987, comprising an infra- structure component, to cover all fixed and operating costs, including return on investment;
a nursing and personal care module, known as the Care Aggregated Module (CAM), introduced from 1 July 1988, and covering the costs of nursing and personal care staff.

The development of uniform funding, in two stages, complements the introduction of quality of life and quality of care standards and the planned introduction of respite care for both hostels and nursing homes and an exempt home concept for nursing homes. These initiatives are resulting in both more equitable and needs-based targeting of resources as well as improved quality of care. A very important element of these changes is that from 1 July 1991, no nursing home resident (apart from those who choose to receive care in exempt homes) will be required to pay more than 87.5% of the sum of the age pension and rent assistance.

Under the new funding arrangements, the Commonwealth will, in effect, fund a specified level of service for nursing home care on behalf of residents at a predetermined price. Emphasis is being placed on outcomes rather than inputs, to give service pro- viders greater flexibility and incentive to increase efficiency, provided that appropriate care and lifestyle outcomes are achieved for residents.

The Department of Community Services and Health released a discussion paper in October 1987 entitled `Equitable Funding Base for Hostels'. This paper has been the subject of extensive consultation with service providers, consumers and their representatives on the implementation of the proposals. Details of the changes developed through the consultation process were announced by me on 17 July 1988. The reforms, which took effect from 11 January 1989, mean that people with limited financial resources will be able to have easier access to hostel care through greatly increased Commonwealth capital subsidies to construct hostel places. Up to $46,400 a place will be available for financially disadvantaged people and for respite care.

Other key features of the hostel changes are greater financial protection for residents who make entry contributions to hostels; greater availability of funds for organisations through relaxed arrangements on the treatment of borrowings.

In addition, there will be easier access for all needing hostel care through increases in the number of new hostel places. This increase is part of the Government's long-term planning strategy, and has been designed specifically to allow a gradual change in the ratio of nursing home to hostel beds to 40:60.

As I have indicated, the introduction of the nursing and personal care funding module for non-Government nursing homes was announced on 21 April 1988, as part of the Stage 4 package of reforms. An extra $130 million over 3 years has been provided to implement this stage of the reforms. This extra funding will, inter alia, provide:
increased hours of care for many highly dependent residents-they will receive up to 27 hours per week;
an across-the-board increase in average hours per resident of almost 1 hour per week;
increased access to therapy and special services; and
further in-service training opportunities for nursing home staff and management.

Currently, the Government's reform strategy is concentrating on the development of mechanisms to enhance the rights of hostel and nursing home residents. I recently released a discussion paper as the basis for further consultation with all interested groups on measures which might be taken to guarantee the rights of frail aged people receiving care.
The studies referred to by the honourable member are all public documents, available either in the Parliamentary Library or at the Commonwealth Government Bookshop.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How are aged care industry costs and care standards to be reviewed.
(2) Will this review be undertaken within his Department or will an independent committee be established.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(2) There are different levels and types of review mechanisms in the aged care program. The extensive consultation process involving industry, union and consumer representatives, for example, provides a mechanism whereby aged care industry cost estimates and care standards are reviewed as they are developed.
(Further information on the basis for calculating aged care industry costs is contained in the answer to Question Number 776.)

Specifically, the level of the Standard Aggregated Module (SAM) funding is adjusted annually on the basis of the official parameters reflecting price and award wage movements and changes in occupational superannuation awards. The Care Aggregated Module (CAM) funding will also be adjusted regularly on the basis of movements in the relevant awards. Discussions with industry bodies about review methodology are now being held.

A range of studies is also being undertaken in conjunction with industry, union and consumer groups, which, inter alia, will examine the relationship between the level of CAM funding and quality of care.
The impact of the new assessment system (the Resident Classification Instrument (RCI)) is being monitored on a regular basis.

A review of outcome standards and standards monitoring procedures is being undertaken this year. Information will be drawn both from the levels of assessed compliance being found by standards monitoring staff and from qualitative input from industry, staff and consumer groups among others.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What facilities exist which meet all expected outcome standards for aged care, at the proposed level of funding and which can be regarded as working examples.
(2) How has his Department quantified care outcome standards and measured these standards.
(3) Will he provide details of the specific quality of care requirements established under his aged care objectives.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(3) As indicated in my answer to Question Number 772, an integral element of the reforms to date has been the introduction of outcome standards for nursing homes. These standards are set out in the Special Gazette S303 (11 November 1987). The gazetted standards are based on standards published in ``Living in a Nursing Home: Outcome Standards for Australian Nursing Homes''. Standards monitoring teams, consisting of medical/nursing and lay members, visit homes to assess compliance with these standards. Compliance is assessed on the demonstrated outcome of services for residents in nursing homes.

However, the factor which most affects the quality of life and care is the efficient and purposeful management of resources in a manner which flexibly addresses the individual needs and wishes of residents. A substantial number of facilities in which standards monitoring has been conducted, have been found to provide adequate care within the existing funding arrangements. This is reflected in their having been assessed as meeting fully or substantially the 31 outcome standards set out in ``Living in a Nursing Home''. A sizeable proportion are homes which have been receiving funding lower than the new standard funding levels. Moreover, under the new Care Aggregated Module (CAM) arrangements, hours (and hence funding) will be linked much more closely with the care needs of nursing home residents. Homes will be accorded far better opportunities to manage their resources flexibly and efficiently to meet the individual service needs of their residents.

Initiatives are being introduced to assist nursing homes to adapt to these more flexible management opportunities. For example, as part of the new arrangements, I announced that an additional $2.75 million will be made available for in-service training for nursing home staff and management assistance for nursing home operators.
Similar outcome standards for hostels will be developed, during 1989, in conjunction with industry, consumer and union representatives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Government use discounted CPI adjustments to extend the infrastructure costs from 1984-85 in developing the standard aggregated module.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The original level of Standard Aggregated Module (SAM) was set using the full CPI and AWE increases over the period from 1984-85 to 1986-87 to adjust the 1984-85 nursing home cost data base. For the final part of that period, indices had not been published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics at the time SAM was set, and Treasury parameters were used instead.

For the 1988-89 SAM, the Government agreed to industry bodies' requests to also make specific provision for the anticipated extra costs of occupational superannuation in the industry. The 1988-89 SAM is therefore calculated using a base figure adjusted for the difference between actual and anticipated cost movements in the previous year, together with an allowance for expected occupational superannuation awards and the 1988-89 CPI and AAW parameters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do his objectives for aged care incorporate a general principle of the right of review or appeal against departmental decisions affecting either individuals or organisations.
(2) Are there rights of appeal or review for the care procedure in relation to care standards and the level of the standard aggregated module (SAM).
(3) Will the level of funding available through SAM meet the true cost of providing the specified level of care and allow the industry to remain financially viable.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Appeal rights have been incorporated in the legislation, wherever needed and practicable. In addition, user rights principles being developed in 1989 will provide safeguards for residents against improper use of authority by care providers.

In particular, there are rights of appeal against, or review of, decisions relating to care standards. The exercise of legal powers under S45E of the National Health Act, for example, to freeze new admissions, may be reviewed by a Standard Review Panel (SRP), where one has been developed.

SRPs were developed because of views expressed by industry, consumer and staff groups, and consist of representatives from those groups. They provide a means for peer review of Departmental recommendations to use legal powers. A panel has already been established in New South Wales and it is intended to set up these panels in all States, in the near future.
In addition, certain decisions are reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. These include the decision to revoke or suspend approval of a home for payment of benefits.

(2) As the level of the Standard Aggregated Module (SAM) is set by formula, there is no exercise of judgement or discretionary powers to warrant a system of appeal. The level of SAM is adjusted annually by applying a formula based on the official parameters to reflect price and award wage movements and changes in occupational superannuation awards.

(3) New standard funding arrangements have led to increased funding for most nursing homes. In conjunction with new staffing funding, these arrangements provide a more realistic and flexible funding system for the provision of appropriate care.

The level of SAM was based on a survey of nursing home operating costs incurred across Australia in 1984-85. The level chosen for SAM was calculated to enable the industry to continue to provide an appropriate level of care and accommodation. About 65% of nursing home beds across Australia received an increase in their real level of funding. All nursing homes have benefited through increased flexibility in management.
While some nursing homes have claimed that their level of profitability has declined, there is no evidence of nursing homes having closed as a result of the new funding system or funding levels.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 13 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the status of Amendment No. 1 to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Food Standards Code, published in the Commonwealth Gazette No. P19 of 15 July 1988.
(2) Does this amendment list some 386 pesticides, antibiotics and veterinary drugs and give the amounts that may be present in a wide range of foods.
(3) Is the Maximum Residue Limit shown in Column 2 of the Schedule the maximum amount of the substance that can be legally present in the food; if not, what do those values represent.

(4) Which committee of the NHMRC sets the Maximum Residue Limits for foods and (a) what are the criteria for setting those limits, (b) who are the members of the committee, (c) what are their qualifications and (d) what organisations do they represent.

(5) Are the Maximum Residue Limits shown in the Gazette uniformly enforceable in all States and Territories; if not, what State or Territory does not include those limits in its legislation or has limits different to those shown in the Gazette.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Amendment No. 1 to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Food Standards Code was approved by the National Food Standards Council in June 1988, with a commencement date of 1 February 1989, other than for a requirement for claims on labels relating to sweetness, which is to commence on 1 August 1990.

(2) &(3) The figures listed in Column 2 of the Schedule of Amendment No. 1 of the Food Standards Code of 15 July 1988 (pp. 58-123) are the Maximum Residue Limits for the substances concerned. The Maximum Residue Limit is the maximum concentration for a residue resulting from the use of a pesticide, agricultural chemical, feed additive or veterinary medicine according to good agricultural practice that is recommended by the NHMRC to be legally permitted or recognised as acceptable in or on a food, agricultural commodity or animal feed. The concentration is expressed in milligrams of residue per kilogram of the commodity.
(4) The Pesticides and Agricultural Chemicals Committee of the NHMRC sets the Maximum Residue Limits for pesticides, agricultural chemicals, feed additives and veterinary medicines:

(a) limits are set such that permitted uses of the chemical will not lead to dietary exposure in excess of the Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) for the chemical. Detailed requirements to establish these limits are set out in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy document PB310B `Requirement for the Clearance of Agricultural Chemicals' (a copy of which has been made available to the honourable member);
(b) &(c) the members of the Pesticides and Agricultural Chemicals Committee as at March 1989 and their qualifications are:
Associate of the Royal Australian Chemical Institute
Associate of the Royal Australian Chemical Institute
Bachelor of Applied Science in Agricultural Chemistry
Fellow of the Royal Australian Chemical Institute
Fellow of the Royal Australian Chemical Institute
Member of the Royal Pharmaceutical Society
Fellow of the Royal Australian Chemical Institute
Associate of the University of Adelaide
(d) Members are selected for their individual expertise and do not represent any organisation.

(5) The National Food Standards Council at its meeting of 14 April 1987 agreed that the Food Standards Code be incorporated into the legislation of the States and the Northern Territory by no later than 1 September 1987. The participation of the Australian Capital Territory Government in the Agreement in relation to the adoption of uniform food standards is currently being negotiated by the Minister for Consumer Affairs.
Although the intention of the Agreement is to provide uniform food standards Australia-wide, the States and the Northern Territory retain the right to vary from the Food Standards Code.
I am aware that two States, Western Australia and South Australia, have deviated from the Maximum Residue Limits shown in the Gazette in one instance in anticipation of forthcoming amendments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Will an increase in stock valuation for taxation purposes from (a) $1 to $4 for sheep and (b) $5 to $20 for cattle, be reflected by an increase in the new compensation figure for the forced destruction of stock through the effects of fire and drought.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is assumed that the compensation arrangements referred to are the provisions under sections 36 and 36aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (ITAA). These set out the method by which compensation received as a result of the forced disposal, death or compulsory destruction of livestock through the effects of fire, drought or flood is to be treated for tax purposes.

For the valuation of natural increase in livestock for tax purposes, prescribed minimum values are provided for by section 34 of the ITAA and specified in Regulation 5 of the Income Tax Regulations. They were last increased on 1 July 1988.

The purpose of the increase in prescribed minimum values was to limit an inappropriate deferral of taxation previously arising from section 34. Before the increase in prescribed minimum values, natural increase in livestock was valued substantially below any reasonable estimate of the cost of natural increase. The increase has brought the tax treatment of the livestock industry more in to line with that of other industries while preserving the administrative advantages of the prescribed value system.

There is no relationship between the prescribed minimum values and compensation received as a result of the forced disposal of stock due to fire or drought and, accordingly, no basis for the latter to be increased as a result of increases in the prescribed minimum values. The value of livestock for compensation purposes is, as provided for in subsection 36 (8), the market value on the day of disposal or such value as the Commissioner considers is fair and reasonable. This value is set by the market, not the Government. Minimum prescribed values relate only to natural increase and, rather than reflecting sale proceeds, are a proxy value for cost of natural increase.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Since the establishment of the (a) Department of Transport and Communications, (b) Federal Airports Corporation and (c) Civil Aviation Authority, what are the details of each contract entered into, including (i) the purpose of the contract, (ii) the goods and services supplied, (iii) its value and duration, (iv) whether the contract went to public tender and, if not, why not, (v) who won the contract and (vi) whether an evaluation has been made of the success of the tender.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The information sought is detailed and is not readily available. I am not prepared to authorise the use of considerable Departmental resources required to answer the question as it stands. However, in relation to contracts which require Ministerial approval under the FAC and CAA Acts I can provide the following information:

(b) (i) Only one contract valued at over $5 million has been entered into by the FAC since its creation on 1 January 1988. The contract was let for principal consultant services for the Stage 1 expansion of the International Terminal Complex at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. (ii) The contractor provided project management and design and documentation services. (iii) The contract value was 11.25% of the completed cost of the constructed work which is estimated to cost $175 million (April 1988 dollars). (iv) The contract did not go to public tender but was negotiated with Kinhill-Stafford Moor and Farrington who were the successful tenderers for the earlier conceptual design part of this project. At the time it was recognised that continuity between the conceptual designs would be desirable to expedite the project. (v) Kinhill-Stafford Moor and Farrington Joint Venture won the contract. (vi) Not applic-able (refer (iv)).

(c) The CAA has entered into two contracts valued at over $6 million since its creation on 1 July 1988. Details of the first are: (i) The purpose of the contract was to provide a national aeronautical information processing system. (ii) The contractor provided General Briefing Units at Brisbane and Melbourne and Remote Briefing Units at Sydney, Adelaide, Perth and Canberra plus spares, training and documentation. (iii) The value of the contract was $13,319,600, and the duration was 42 months. (iv) The contract went to public tender. (v) MacDonald, Dettwiler and Associates Ltd won the contract. (vi) Contract completion is not due until September 1991 so no evaluation has been made.

Details of the second contract are as follows: (i) The purpose of the contract was to provide office accommodation for Canberra staff. (ii) The contract was to purchase the National Convention Centre Building No. 6 in Canberra. (iii) The purchase price of the building was $49,331,000. (iv) The contract did not go to public tender. The public tender pro-cess is not applicable to the purchase of buildings and the CAA made a commercial decision to acquire the accommodation. (v) National Convention Corporation Pty Ltd was awarded the contract. (vi) Not applicable (refer (iv)).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the legal basis on which separate and special landing charges are imposed by the Federal Airports Corporation on some operators at some airports.
(2) Has there been a dispute where some operators claim that those charges are in fact taxes and are discriminatory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The FAC's aeronautical charges are levied under determinations made pursuant to Section 56 of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1987. The FAC does not impose separate and special charges on particular operators.
(2) Some operators have disputed some FAC charges and have referred to FAC landing charges as Government taxes or discriminatory charges.

Section 56 (10) of the FAC Act specifies that an aeronautical charge shall not be fixed at an amount that exceeds the amount that is reasonably related to the expenses incurred or to be incurred by the Corporation in relation to the matters in respect of which the charge is payable and shall not be such as to amount to taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are (a) the income of, and (b) donations to, the Tasmanian Wilderness Society tax exempt?
(2) Can donations be made exempt by being given via the Australian Conservation Foundation?
(3) Has his attention been drawn to an admission in the Weekend Australian, 4-5 March 1989, page 28, that the Tasmanian Wilderness Society funds the election campaigns of so-called Independents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Due to the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act the Commissioner of Taxation was unable to comment on whether the income of the Tasmanian Wilderness Society is exempt from income tax. However, he was able to advise that donations to the Society do not qualify for deduction under the gift provisions of the Act.

(2) Donations of $2 and upwards made to the Australian Conservation Foundation may qualify for deduction. The Foundation's constitution enables it to provide assistance to, or to cooperate with other bodies concerned with or interested in conservation. Tax deductibility depends on whether the donations are made to the Foundation in its own right, or to the Foundation merely acting as a trustee or agent for donations intended for some other organisation or purpose. In the former case the donations would qualify for deduction as the Foundation would have an unfettered discretion to deal with the donations as it sees fit in accordance with its approved aims. In the latter case, no deduction would be allowable.
(3) I am aware of the statement in the article and I have asked the Commissioner to examine the matter to ensure that the tax law is being complied with.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 4 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) propose to remove Distance Measuring Equipment (DME) from Normanton and Hughenden Airport; if so, (a) why is this action being proposed and (b) when will it be implemented.
(2) If this equipment is removed, how does the CAA propose that aircraft operating on International Flight Rules establish ground speed reference.
(3) Why was the DME installed in the first place in these locations.
(4) What justifies the removal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Civil Aviation Authority is not proposing to remove Distance Measuring Equipment from Normanton and Hughenden. Should the aviation industry not be agreeable to pay the cost of provision and operation of international standard Distance Measuring Equipment in the future, the CAA may propose removal of these navigation aids. See also (4) below.
(2) By reference to Non-Directional Beacons (NDBs) alone.

(4) The removal of the existing Australian standard DME at Hughenden and Normanton, (and non-replacement of these aids with international standard DME), would only be justified if the aviation industry is not prepared to continue to pay for the cost of provision and operation of the aids, through the CAA's cost recovery program.

In response to recent representations by several regional operators of supplementary airlines, the CAA has requested that representatives of the aviation industry clarify their requirements for the continued provision of DME at six remote locations throughout Australia, including Normanton and Hughenden.

These six locations each have Australian standard DME, but have not previously received industry endorsement for replacement with international standard DME. If the aviation industry, through its acknowledged consultative representatives, advises its willingness to continue to pay for these aids in future, they will be retained. On the other hand, if the industry indicates that it is not willing to pay for these aids, the CAA would remove the existing Australian standard DME equipment in late 1994, and would not replace it with International standard DME.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 4 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has her attention been drawn to a meeting of the Sydney Airport Crew Monitoring Committee which was held at Petersham Town Hall on 8 February 1989.

(2) Was an official report of the meeting prepared; if so, (a) has she been briefed on the meeting, (b) will she provide a copy of the report and (c) were representatives of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) present.
(3) Is she able to say who was present at the meeting.

(4) Did the Curfew Monitoring Committee seek the release of air traffic controllers tapes of radar plots of aircraft flight paths over Sydney; if so, is she able to say why release of the tapes was sought.
(5) Does the Government provide any support to the Sydney Airport Curfew Monitoring Committee; if so, (a) what is the support and (b) what does it cost.
(6) Is she able to say what functions a consultant to the Committee, Mr T Williams performs.
(7) Was she advised by the CAA concerning the request for release of the tapes referred to in part (4); if so, (a) what was that advice and (b) what was her response.
(8) If the tapes are not to be released, why not.

(9) Have draft regulations been prepared to provide penalties for breaches of the curfew hours or the creation of excessive noise during curfew hours; if so, (a) will she provide details of the draft regulations, particularly the proposed penalties, (b) at whose suggestion were the draft regulations prepared and (c) when will they be implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The meeting was of a working group of the Curfew Monitoring Committee and was held at Marrickville Municipal Council offices at Petersham.
(2) Minutes of the meeting of the working group were prepared by the Secretariat.
(a) The previous Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support was represented at the meeting.
(b) Yes. A copy of the minutes has been provided separately.
(3) Yes. The minutes of the meeting include an attendance list.
(4) Some elements of the Committee sought release of the tapes because they believed the information would assist the Committee in its role of monitoring the curfew.

(a) Secretarial Services are provide by the Civil Aviation Authority. The Authority is also undertaking noise studies to assist the Committee in its evaluation of the effects of the revised curfew. The Government pays a fee to members of the Committee, other than public servants or representatives of Government business enterprises.

(b) The Civil Aviation Authority estimates the secretarial services cost approximately $8,000 a year. The noise studies undertaken by the Authority use staff and information which are also required for other purposes and it is not practical to separately estimate the cost of the noise studies for the Committee. Fees are paid at rates set by the remuneration tribunal and, if all nominated members attend, the cost is estimated at $952 per meeting.
(6) Mr T Williams is a consultant to local councils on the Committee, not a consultant to the Committee.
(7) Yes. The former Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support was advised of the request for the release of the tapes and declined to accede to that request.

(8) The tapes containing the recordings of the information from the radar have not been released because the data was not in a format suitable for the purposes of the Curfew Committee. The conversion of the data into a format which may have been useful would be both complex and expensive.
Additionally, there was some concern that the data contained in the tapes may have been used for purposes for which it was neither intended nor suitable.
(9) Draft Regulations are being prepared and are proposed to include penalties for breaches of the curfew.
(a) Yes. A copy of the draft regulations has been provided separately.
(b) The Regulations are being prepared in accordance with Senator Evans' announcement of the trial of the new noise reduction strategy.
(c) The Regulations will come into effect when the necessary consultative, administrative and legal processes are completed.

(2) How many individuals have been granted places.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At 31 March 1989, 514 applications had been received for the Attendant Care Scheme.
(2) At 31 March 1989, 183 people had been approved to join the Attendant Care Scheme, and an additional 62 people were being assessed for participation on the Scheme.
(3) (a) To be eligible for the Attendant Care Scheme, applicants must meet the following criteria:
Be aged from 16 to 64 years inclusive.
Be living in a nursing home at the time of application:

long-term hospital patients may be eligible if their current stay in hospital exceeds 35 days and they are regarded by that hospital as being a `nursing home' patient and if residence in the hospital is seen as their only permanent living option;
occupants of respite beds in nursing homes may be eligible if:
(a) the applicant is occupying a bed in a nursing home at the time of application;
(b) the applicant has occupied a bed in a nursing home for at least 130 nights during the twelve-month period immediately prior to application; and

up to 28 hours support per week is provided under the Scheme.

Resident in nursing home (or other eligible setting) ...
No more than 28 support hours required from Scheme ...
Health care needs can be met in community ...

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say what tax shelters exist overseas for Australian companies to minimise their tax obligations.
(2) Is he able to estimate how much taxable income from Australian companies has been channelled to tax havens such as the Cook Islands since 1983; if not, why not.
(3) How long has he been aware of the opportu-nities for Australian companies to minimise their tax obligations by channelling taxable income to tax havens.

(4) Is it a fact that during the 1985 review of the taxation system, he was provided with information indicating the possible extent of tax sheltering acti-vities, including the use of tax havens, which was subsequently published in the draft White Paper Reform of the Australian Taxation System.
(5) What specific action has he taken since the 1985 review to address specific problems regarding tax havens.
(6) If action has been taken since the 1985 review, why has no legislation been introduced to outlaw the use of tax havens.
(7) Why will no legislative measures be introduced to close tax haven loopholes until 1990-91, nearly three years after they were announced in draft form in the May 1988 Economic Statement.
(8) Will he take action to expedite any legislative measures; if not, why not.

(9) Is it a fact that an Ansett Airlines subsidiary co-owned by Sir Peter Abeles and Rupert Murdoch shifted $100m through a tax shelter in the Cook Islands in the last year; if so, is this transaction in accordance with the Government's policy of preventing tax evasion and avoidance and maintaining a fair and equitable tax system.

(10) Will the Government introduce retrospective legislation to recoup revenue owed to the Commonwealth as a result of companies using tax havens similar to that introduced by the Fraser Government in respect of `bottom of the harbour' tax schemes in the early 1980s; if not, why not.

(11) Is he able to estimate what sum would have been effectively lost to the Commonwealth since he became aware of the tax haven problem if no legislative measures are introduced until 1990-91; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Tax shelters-of one type or another-exist in most tax jurisdictions. Compiling a list of all tax shelters that exist offshore for Australian companies to minimise their tax obligations would be a complex and lengthy task and would require the diversion of more departmental resources than I am prepared to authorise for that purpose. If the honourable member has a particular interest in tax havens, again no definitive list exists. However, tax jurisdictions offering significant tax benefits have been omitted from the list of comparable-tax countries published on 12 April 1989 in the Information Paper on the Taxation of Foreign Source Income.
(2) No; a distinction must be made between taxable income illegally channelled to tax havens and income sourced in the tax haven.

If an Australian company channels taxable income to a tax haven and by so doing escapes paying Australian tax on that income, it does so in breach of Australia's income tax law. There are comprehensive provisions in Australia's income tax law designed to deal with practices, such as transfer pricing, that could be used to attempt to channel Australian-source income to, and to source it artificially in, tax havens. By its nature, such activity is hidden from the Australian Taxation Office and it is therefore not possible to estimate how much taxable income-if any-has been channelled to tax havens since 1983. Such activities could be identified subsequently during taxation audits.

For the most part, the tax avoidance mischief that is done through tax havens is about gaining a tax deferral on income that is not taxable in Australia until it is distributed to its Australian beneficial owners.

Until the 1987-88 income year (when the Government introduced the foreign tax credit system (FTCS)), most foreign source income of Australian companies was exempt from Australian corporate tax. It can hardly be said that Australian companies were avoiding tax on such income, when the law specifically exempted it from tax.

At present, foreign source income of Australian companies that is derived indirectly through a non-resident company is not taxable income in Australia until it is distributed to its Australian beneficial owners. That is, the FTCS does not expose to tax profits retained in companies established abroad. So long as income derived through a foreign company is retained and accumulated offshore it remains outside the scope of Australia's income tax law. The longer income can be retained in a tax haven and the Australian tax liability deferred, the lower will be the real effective tax rate on that income.

To obtain this deferral advantage, it is not sufficient that a company is merely incorporated offshore. Australia's income tax law contains provisions relating to place of residence of a company which are based on broader considerations than simply place of incorporation. Under Section 6 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, a company not incorporated in Australia may, nevertheless, be treated as a resident of Australia if its central management and control is in Australia.

(3) I have been aware of the opportunities for Australian companies to minimise their tax obligations by using companies resident in tax havens for many years. Such opportunities have existed for as long as tax havens.
However, those opportunities do not derive from Australian companies channelling taxable domestic income to tax havens-see my answer to (2).

(4) No; some information on tax sheltering activities was published in Chapter 4 of the draft white paper Reform of the Australian Taxation System. However, no information indicating the possible extent of tax sheltering activities, including the use of tax havens, was published in the draft white paper.

Indeed, it is very difficult to estimate the extent of tax sheltering activities through the use of tax havens. Companies resident in tax havens are generally required to lodge tax returns in Australia only if they derive Australian-source income; most of these companies do not lodge returns in Australia. Companies resident in Australia lodge tax returns under our self-assessment system. Subsequent audits, conducted by the Australian Taxation Office, will pick up unlawful activities associated with subsidiaries resident in tax havens.

The published annual reports of Australian companies detail the contribution to accounting profit of subsidiaries incorporated in tax havens. However, accounting profit often bears little or no correlation with taxable income. Because of this, the published reports are of no help in estimating the amount of taxable income derived in tax havens by entities whose ultimate beneficial owners are Australian residents.
(5) Since the 1985 review, the Government has overhauled the taxation of foreign source income:
the foreign tax credit system was introduced with effect from the 1987-88 income year;

a Consultative Document, Taxation of Foreign Source Income, was released as part of the May 1988 Economic Statement; it contained initial details of proposed new rules for taxing income derived in tax havens by Australian residents as it is earned; and

following extensive consultation with business and the professions, I announced on 12 April 1989 the final design of those comprehensive new rules for taxing foreign source income derived from companies, trusts and other arrangements.

The new rules, which are outlined in detail in the Information Paper on Taxation of Foreign Source Income, released as part of the April 1989 Economic Statement, will thwart the use of tax havens to avoid Australian tax.
These policy changes accord with the proposals contained in the draft white paper (at pp. 232-253).
Moreover, the Government introduced a full imputation system with effect from 1 July 1987. Imputation provides a significant incentive for Australian companies to derive Australian-source income.

In addition to these policy changes, the Australian Taxation Office has taken a number of comprehensive measures in recent years to raise its profile in the area of international tax compliance. These include:
the establishment of an International Operations (now Complex Audit and International) Branch in 1983 to oversee and coordinate international tax compliance;
the establishment of international audit teams in all major branches;
the implementation of an international enforcement strategy to ensure a continuing commitment to international audits;
a focus on the auditing of large corporate groups with an emphasis on international issues;
a program of industry-wide audits with an emphasis on those companies with international transactions;
several specific projects on international issues have been initiated-eg, on royalties and on re-invoicing;
the development of a computer-based case selection system for international issues;
active exchange of information and cooperation with tax treaty partners; and
the development of introductory and intermediate training packages on international issues.
Each of these initiatives addresses, in part, specific problems regarding tax havens.
(6) The Australian Government does not have the authority to outlaw the use of tax havens. In any case, such a course of action would be both unnecessary and undesirable.

There are legitimate reasons for Australian companies to operate in tax havens. This has been explicitly recognised in the new rules for taxing foreign source income that I announced on 12 April. Those new rules will thwart the use of tax havens to avoid Australian tax, while maintaining the competitiveness of Australian companies operating in low-tax jurisdictions for genuine business reasons.

(7) As I explained in my press releases of 21 December 1988 and 12 April 1989, the delay in implementing the accruals tax measures arises from the consultative process with business and tax professionals begun in May last year and from the extremely complex nature of this area of tax law.

The design of the new rules for taxing foreign source income has benefited from the consultative process. The Government is committed to that process and has accepted the necessary delay in implementing the new measures.

The consultative process is particularly useful in such a complex area of tax law. The complexity, also evident in comparable foreign legislation, reflects the balance that has to be struck between fostering genuine business activities and eradicating tax avoidance. The integration of issues raised in the consultative process has ensured that the draft legislation, which will be released in the 1989 Budget sittings, will attain the appropriate balance.

(8) No; given the complexity of the new rules which are necessary to thwart complex tax haven avoidance schemes, the drafting of workable and effective legislation cannot be rushed. Moreover, the Government remains committed to the consultative process and will be inviting comments from interested parties on technical aspects of the draft legislation.
The new measures will apply from the start of the 1990-91 income year (just over 2 years after the May 1988 announcement). For early balancing companies this could be as early as 1 December 1989.

(9) The secrecy provisions of Australian income tax law prevent the Commissioner of Taxation and his officers from disclosing the income tax affairs of an individual taxpayer without the express authority to do so. I am therefore unable to answer this part of the honourable member's question.

(10) No; provisions already exist in the income tax legislation to collect any tax owed to the Australian revenue. Moreover, companies resident in tax havens are often used to defer Australian tax. In such cases, an Australian tax liability may not arise until the income is distributed to the Australian beneficial owners. If the distribution has not occurred, no revenue may be owing to the Government.

(11) As I explained in my answer to (2), Australian companies can minimise their tax liabilities by using companies resident in tax havens to defer Australian taxation. As such, the tax is not effectively lost to Australian revenue, but is deferred to future years. Moreover, my answer to (4) detailed some of the problems in obtaining reliable revenue estimates in this area other than by tax audits of Australian companies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the value of the contract let for the supply of general purpose office chairs for Commonwealth departments and authorities.
(2) What were the criteria for testing the chairs.
(3) Is testing of chairs or other goods carried out by an independent authority.
(4) Is it customary for tenderers or a nominated representative to be present when chairs or other goods are tested; if not, why not.
(5) What was the price per unit of the chairs supplied by the successful tenderer.
(6) How did that price compare with those submitted by the other tenderers.
(7) What was the difference in price between the chairs supplied by the successful tenderer and those of the previous supplier.
(8) Did the chairs submitted by the successful tenderer meet the specifications set out in the original tender documents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The estimated value of the period contract is $18 million, with an estimated annual expenditure of $6 million.

(2) I am advised by my Department that the performance specification prepared by Worksafe Australia, Australian Construction Services and the Purchasing and Sales Group formed the basis for the evaluation. The criteria against which the chairs were assessed were drawn from the specification. Major areas of assessment included ergonomics, construction, safety, maintenance and price. Ergonomics was considered to be the most important category.

(3) The contract was arranged by the Commonwealth Government's specialist, independent purchasing authority, the Purchasing and Sales Group. Where tenders are required to comply with a technical specification and the expertise necessary to evaluate those tenders is not available from within the Purchasing and Sales Group, independent experts are called upon to provide the relevant advice.

In the case of the general purpose office chairs contract, I am advised that testing and assessment for compliance with the specification was carried out by an evaluation committee comprising representatives of the Purchasing and Sales Group, an architect from Australian Construction Services and a physiotherapist from Worksafe Australia. The National Building Technology Centre in Sydney was engaged to measure the sample chairs to assess whether they conformed to the dimensional requirements of the specification.
(4) No. My Department does not invite tenderers or their representatives to be present during testing of sample goods for the following reasons:
to protect the confidentiality of all tenderers;
to keep evaluation costs to a minimum;
to minimise the potential for disputes prior to decision-making; and,
to reduce the potential for increased evaluation time.

(5) The price per unit of chairs varied from state to state as did the estimated quantity of chairs required. The price of a chair, with arms, delivered FIS into Sydney, was $207.50 less 2.5% discount for payment within 30 days.

(6) I am advised that the Co Design offer was the eighteenth lowest in price from 28 complete offers. I am further advised that the seventeen lower priced offers were passed over because they failed to comply with one or more of the mandatory requirements of the specification.

(7) There was no previous contract for an ergonomic general purpose office chair so a price comparison is not valid. The previous supplier of standard clerical chairs was Office Furniture Discounts. That contract expired in September 1986. The price per unit at that time was $60.63.
(8) Yes. I am advised that the ``Unomanic'' chair submitted by Co. Design met all mandatory requirements of the specification.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 May 1989:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 4 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, (a) on what basis does each State charge their tenants rent for public housing, (b) does the Agreement provide for assessed income of tenants to include (i) Austudy, (ii) Family Allowance and (iii) Family Allowance Supplement, (c) which States include in the assessment of income of their tenants (i) Austudy, (ii) Family Allowance and (iii) Family Allowance Supplement, (d) does the inclusion of Austudy, Family Allowance or Family Allowance Supplement in the assessment of income for public tenants meet the social justice concerns of the Federal Government and (e) what action, if any, does he propose to take on this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) State and Territorial Governments have responsibility for the detailed administration of funds provided under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA). This responsibility includes determining public housing rental policies. Rent-setting policies vary from State to State, the majority (Victoria, Western Australia, Tasmania and Northern Territory) using cost rent formulae, others (Tasmania, Queensland) set rents according to tenant income, the New South Wales recently announced that it is about to introduce a procedure based on market rents.
(b) The Agreement currently does not specify how income is to be assessed for public housing tenants.

(c) In accordance with a decision reached at the 1988 Housing Ministers' Conference, all States include approximately 15% of the Family Allowance Supplement in their calculation of assessable income for public housing tenants. No State includes Family Allowance payments in these calculations. The treatment of Austudy varies according to whether the Austudy recipient is a dependant of the tenant or a tenant in his or her own right. In the latter case, Austudy usually is the predominant or only source of household income and is treated as income for rent assessment purposes. (These tenants usually qualify for the full rental rebate). Where dependants of tenants are in receipt of Austudy, the treatment varies. A majority of States (Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania) include a small component and the remainder (New South Wales, Northern Territory and Australian Capital Territory) exclude Austudy from rent assessment procedures.

(d) The Commonwealth Government has recently introduced or upgraded a number of special purpose benefits for low income households in line with its social justice strategy for all Australians. State Housing Authorities have co-operated in this endeavour through the procedures described above.

(e) Under the terms of the Commonwealth's recently announced proposal for a new CSHA, States will be required to assess special purpose benefits, for public housing rent setting purposes, in a way consistent with the Commonwealth's social justice strategy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 8 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say what the incidence is of skin cancers or other cancers among returned Antarctic Division Expeditioners; if so, is there any evidence that the incidence has increased during the period of depletion of the ozone layer over Antarctica.

(2) What steps has the Antarctic Division taken in response to increased awareness of the possible impact on health of an increased exposure to ultraviolet radiation of people employed at the Antarctic bases or permanent staff who regularly travel to the bases.
(3) What precautionary measures has the Division taken to warn of the risks involved in exposure to sunlight in Antarctica and to require protective measures by all personnel visiting Antarctica.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Antarctic Division has not carried out studies of the incidence of skin or other cancers on returned expeditioners. Given that skin cancers develop over extended periods and that most expeditioners are employed for periods of less than two years it would be difficult for the Division to conduct such studies. The lifestyle in Antarctica is such that exposure to the sun is limited.
(2) The Antarctic Division, in association with the Australian Radiation Laboratories, has commenced a program to monitor the levels of ultra- violet radiation at Casey, Davis and Mawson.

(3) It is the practice of the Antarctic Division to warn personnel visiting Antarctica of the risks of ultraviolet radiation and to advise them to wear goggles and apply sunscreen to exposed skin as a precaution against injuries such as snowblindness and sunburn.

(2) Does AN obtain (a) a rent for the space occupied, (b) a commission on turnover or (c) any other form of payment from the Democratic Club.
