QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the (a) name and (b) rank of the person who represents the Australian Government on (i) the World Bank and (ii) the Asian Development Bank.

(2) For each person in part (1), (a) what was the process of selection, (b) who was responsible for the appointment of the person, (c) what section of the Department of the Treasury did the person come from and (d) is that person the sole Australian Government representative on the respective institution.
(3) How often do delegates of countries to (a) the World Bank and (b) the Asian Development Bank meet to discuss and deliberate on development projects.
(4) Is he able to provide dates of such meetings of (a) the World Bank and (b) the Asian Development Bank for (i) 1988, (ii) 1989 and (iii) the future; if not, why not.
(5) Are the records of such meetings of (a) the World Bank and (b) the Asian Development Bank publicly available; if not, who has access to the records.

(6) Is a record of Australia's position on each development proposal before (a) the World Bank and (b) the Asian Development Bank available to (i) the Australian public or (ii) members of this Parliament; if not (A) why not and (B) to whom do the Australian delegates report on what projects Australia has approved.

(7) What action has the Australian Government taken in its involvement in (a) the World Bank and (b) the Asian Development Bank to ensure that development projects do not result in environmental degradation or do not disadvantage the poorer sections of a country's population.
(8) What action has the Australian Government taken in its involvement in (a) the World Bank and (b) the Asian Development Bank to prevent the further deforestation of the Amazon rainforests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The positions of Governor and Alternate Governor in both the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the World Bank are held by the Treasurer and the Director of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), respectively. On the Board of Directors of the World Bank, Australia is represented by Mr Chang Yuel Lim, Executive Director; Mr Robert Carling is the Alternate Executive Director, and Mr Dennis Fitzgerald is one of the Executive Director's Assistants. Australia is represented on the Board of Directors of the ADB by Mr Ken Waller, Executive Director; Mr Derek Rooken-Smith is the Alternate Executive Director.

(2) Mr Chang Yuel Lim is a Korean who was nominated by the Government of the Republic of Korea for election. He was elected by Governors of countries in the Constituency to the position of Executive Director;

Mr Carling was Assistant Secretary, Economic Branch, General Financial and Economic Policy Division in the Department of the Treasury. His selection was based on a Treasury interview and selection process. He was appointed by the Executive Director.
Mr Fitzgerald was AIDAB's country program manager for PNG. His appointment was recommended by AIDAB following an AIDAB selection and interview process. Appointment was made by the Executive Director.

Mr Waller was Assistant Secretary, Banking and Finance Branch, Finance and Investment Division, in the Treasury prior to taking up the Director's position in December 1987; his selection was based on a Treasury interview and selection process and his nomination was approved by AIDAB. He was then nominated by the Treasurer for election by Governors of countries in the Constituency to the position of Executive Director.

Mr Rooken-Smith was Director, International Financial Institutions Section in AIDAB prior to taking up his appointment in May 1989; Mr Rooken-Smith was appointed following a selection process involving an interview Committee organised by AIDAB on which Treasury was represented. He was then appointed by Mr Waller as the Executive Director.

(3) Governors of the World Bank meet twice a year in the Development Committee, usually in April and September, and at the Annual Meeting, usually held in September. The Executive Directors meet as often as the business of the World Bank requires them to meet, usually two days each week.
Governors of the ADB meet annually to discuss matters of Bank policy. Directors' meetings are usually held weekly throughout the year. In 1988 there were 45 meetings of the Board of Directors.
Discussions in the Governing and Executive bodies of the World Bank and the ADB are not restricted to development project proposals and include other policy and administrative matters.

(4) Meetings of the Development committee were held on 15 April 1988, 26 September 1988, 4 April 1989 and are scheduled for 25 September 1989, April 1990 (date to be fixed), and September 1990 (date to be fixed).
The World Bank Annual Meeting takes place in September, following the Development Committee meeting.
Annual meetings of the ADB were held on 28-30 April 1988 and 4-6 May 1989.
The dates of Annual Meetings of both Banks in 1990 and beyond have not been finalised.

(5) Records of Executive Board meetings of the World Bank and the ADB are not publicly available. These documents contain sensitive financial data and reports of confidential negotiations between the Bank and officials of recipient countries. Treasury and AIDAB receive copies of summary reports of Board meetings.

Records of the Annual meetings of the Board of Governors of the World Bank and the ADB are publicly available. These records include statements of Governors at Annual Meetings. Records of Development Committee meetings are not released. Communiques from meetings, however, are publicly available and statements made by members are often released publicly by them.

(6) Our executive Directors in the World Bank and the ADB report to the Treasury and AIDAB on the positions they have taken on policy proposals and the more important project proposals and the outcome of meetings. These reports are not generally available to the Parliament or the public. However, such reports may be released on request provided they do not contain information which is considered confidential or sensitive and which might prejudice on-going negotiations or bilateral relations with other members.
(7) The Australian Government has been a leading supporter of the following recent measures to improve the effectiveness and accountability of the World Bank's environmental work:
implementation of World Bank policies and procedures designed to ensure that World Bank projects do not result in environmental degradation;
establishment of a new Environment Department within the World Bank and four regional environmental sub-units in the Bank's operations complex;
greater World Bank role in environment education for policymakers in LDCs; and
improved reporting on environmental aspects of the Bank's operations.
To further enhance the Bank's environmental work, we have informed the Bank and other members that we would like to see:
public availability of this information; and
enhanced dialogue with non-government organisations and relevant international agencies.
Our Executive Director has also sought improvements to environmental components of individual loans.

Our Director in the ADB is concerned to see that development projects do not result in environmental degradation. In general this is achieved through influencing the Bank's policy guidelines and operating procedures to make them sensitive to this issue. In 1987 our Alternate Director did not support a loan proposal for a paper mill in Nepal, because of inadequate environmental provisions.

(8) Australia has supported World Bank assistance to the Brazilian authorities to establish mechanisms to address existing and future environmental issues and examine ongoing projects to determine to what extent remedial environmental measures are necessary. Following representations from Australia and other countries, the proposed Electric Power Sector II loan to Brazil was recently suspended and the Bank is working on a large environment sector loan for Brazil.
The ADB does not lend to Brazil or have any other involvement in that country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 25 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum did the Capricornia College of Advanced Education (CAE) pay the Bundaberg TAFE College for the lease of 8 rooms at a site owned by the Bundaberg City Council who were in turn leasing the site to the TAFE College.
(2) Why were such arrangements considered necessary.
(3) Is the Bundaberg TAFE College capable of handling the students at the leased site at its own campus.
(4) Why did the Capricornia CAE move its campus from the Christian Brothers site in Bundaberg to the Bright Horizons site, also in Bundaberg.
(5) Is the Bundaberg TAFE campus being fully used for the provision of tertiary studies.
(6) Has he or his Department received any correspondence requesting consideration for a new University or TAFE site in Bundaberg; if so, who are the principals involved.
(7) Are there plans to establish a TAFE facility within land adjacent to the Bundaberg Airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1, 2, &4) Commonwealth funds are provided to higher education institutions in the form of a block grant, and the institutions themselves are responsible for their own management. The arrangement the Capricornia College of Advanced Education had with the Bundaberg TAFE College in relation to the leasing of rooms is, therefore, an internal matter.
The Capricornia Institute of Advanced Education has, however, volunteered the following information to my Department about the leasing of facilities in Bundaberg:
In September 1987, Capricornia raised with Bundaberg College of TAFE the possibility of leasing facilities to offer the first year of their Bachelor of Business degree in Bundaberg in 1988.

When no teaching facilities were available at the TAFE campus, TAFE leased three rooms at the Bundaberg Higher Education Centre (owned by the City Council and used for a range of general educational purposes). They in turn leased these to Capricornia along with an office on the TAFE campus. Apparently arrangements were also made for Capricornia to share the TAFE library facilities. Although no clear information has been forwarded about the cost of these leasing arrangements, a figure of $6,000 has been mentioned for the re-lease of three rooms by Capricornia from TAFE.

During 1988 Capricornia decided that facilities were unsatisfactory (dust, traffic, distance from TAFE library). Following further discussions with TAFE they decided that the most satisfactory solution was to lease the ``Bright Horizons'' facilities for three years from 1989 to cater for existing provision and further expansion in Bundaberg.

The sharing of TAFE facilities is an important means of expanding opportunities for higher education study, particularly in non-metropolitan localities too small to justify a separate higher education institution. I would, therefore, expect the Capricornia Institute of Advanced Education to continue to pursue with the TAFE authorities at Bundaberg ways of further enhancing co-operative arrangements and hence, higher education provision.
(3 &5) This is a matter for the Queensland TAFE authorities.
(6) The Commonwealth is not aware of any requests for the establishment of a new university or TAFE college in Bundaberg.
(7) The Commonwealth has not received any requests for the establishment of a new TAFE facility in Bundaberg.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 29 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the special purpose grant for wheat freight subsidy to Tasmania to be reduced by 25 per cent over five years.

(2) If the subsidy is to be reduced, is the decision based on a claim that there is scope to find inefficiencies in the handling of wheat shipments to Tasmania; if so, where and in what form are inefficiencies occurring in the handling of wheat shipments to Tasmania.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Government announced on 21 February 1989 that freight assistance on wheat shipped to Tasmania would be funded from Consolidated Revenue under the new wheat marketing arrangements and that the level of assistance would be reduced by 25 per cent over the next five years. The scheme would be subject to review before the end of that period.

(2) This decision was based on information provided in a number of reports which suggested that there were inefficiencies in the current storage and unloading arrangements for wheat shipped to Tasmania.

(a) Statements from the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) referred to in both the 1983 and 1988 Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) Reports on the Wheat Industry, suggested that past subsidy arrangements which covered the full shipping costs had led to inadequacies in the Tasmanian storage and unloading systems and, as a consequence, to increased freight costs.

(b) The AWB submission to the 1987 IAC Inquiry into Coastal Shipping stated the ``Tasmanian storage system is inadequate to handle any reasonable size shipments of wheat.'' The AWB estimated that the average freight rate could be reduced by about $4 per tonne if it was able to offer maximum ship loads of 27,000 t compared to the usual shipment of only about 19,000 t (for 3 port discharge). For a single port discharge, savings of about $9 per tonne were estimated. However, it was suggested that single port delivery may not be cost effective because of current road and rail arrangements.

(c) The Inter-State Commission (ISC) in its 1985 report on the shipment of wheat to Tasmania also indicated savings of around $5 per tonne if full load shipments (24,500 t at that time) were possible. The ISC recognised that there were problems of storing and handling wheat in Tasmania and recommended that a conference be held to resolve these.

Against this background the Government considered that it was reasonable for the freight assistance to be phased down by 25 per cent over five years to provide a suitable incentive for the achievement of cost savings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to provide ship-day figures by (a) month (b) ship type for Soviet ships deployed in the Indian Ocean from 1984 to 1989.
(2) What effect has the Soviet base at Cam Ranh Bay had on Soviet naval deployments in the Indian Ocean.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For the reasons outlined in the answer to Question No. 514 (Hansard, 18 February 1988, page 352), it would not be in Australia's security interest to provide the detailed information sought. Rounded annual figures for the number of ship-days spent by Soviet naval vessels in the Indian Ocean were provided for 1984 to 1986 in the answer to Question No. 557 (Hansard, 22 August 1988, page 37). The subsequent figures (rounded to the nearest hundred days) are: 1987, 5500; 1988, 6100; and 1989 (to March), 1600.

(2) When the USSR has naval forces stationed at Cam Ranh Bay, use of the facility reduces the time in which it can deploy forces to the Indian Ocean. Formerly the nearest Soviet Pacific base was in Vladivostok. The distance saving is about 2400 nautical miles.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 29 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Is any Australian research in the area of medium-term climatic prediction being conducted to identify the likelihood of drought in the 1990s; if so (a) what is the nature of the research, (b) what organisations are involved and (c) what funds are available to them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Climate research has been an ongoing component of the research programs of the Bureau of Meteorology and the CSIRO for many years. Several universities are also actively involved. The understanding of climate processes and the development of climate (including drought) prediction capabilities are primary objectives of the World Climate Research Programme. The Bureau of Meteorology and the Academy of Sciences' National Committee for Atmospheric Sciences jointly sponsor the `Australian Committee for the World Climate Research Programme' which regularly reviews national research in this area and provides a coordinating mechanism for Australian input to the international program.

The controls over medium-term climate variability are global. Australia is already benefiting from the international research effort through application of the existing knowledge of the linked phenomena of the E1 Nino in the equatorial Pacific Ocean and the Southern Oscillation in the atmosphere for the provision of general estimates of likely seasonal rainfall. It has been established that the fluctuations of the E1 Nino and the Southern Oscillation explain a large proportion of the variability of rainfall over eastern Australia. The Bureau of Meteorology formally commenced a Seasonal Climate Outlook Service in June 1989 based on direct correlations between rainfall over particular areas and an index of the Southern Oscillation. Although there are other contributing factors to rainfall variability, the correlations with the Southern Oscillation are sufficiently strong to enable the Bureau to provide useful information on the likelihood of droughts over eastern Australia several months ahead.

The likelihood of drought in the 1990s and later may also be dependent on continuing long-term changes in the Australian climate which have been observed to be occurring over the past 40 years. These changes could be as a result of the so-called greenhouse effect or as a result of natural variability of the climate system. The same research studies and models that are being developed to understand and predict the natural variability of climate will be used to assess the effects of increasing greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. It is expected that as a result of funds recently provided by the Government to strengthen this research effort, it will be possible within the next three to four years to provide a preliminary assessment of the areas of Australia that may become more subject to drought as a result of the increasing build-up of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.
In response to the honourable member's specific questions (a), (b) and (c), the answers are as follows:
(a) The continuing research effort involves three main components:
observation and analysis of the atmospheric and oceanic circulation of the Australian and neighbouring regions, and the exchange of data with overseas groups;

identification and specification of important climate processes, including energy exchange at the atmospheric boundary, the water cycle involving evaporation and cloud formation, and ice edge dynamics; and
(b) The main organisations carrying out the research are as follows:

The Bureau of Meteorology which maintains the observing network, data communications and processing systems, and climate archives for ongoing atmospheric monitoring. The Bureau of Meteorology Research Centre is analysing the observed data to identify the causes of climate fluctuations, such as drought in the Australian region, and its modelling expertise is being applied to develop a climate prediction capacity using the recently acquired Bureau supercomputer;

The CSIRO Division of Atmospheric Research which has active programs of research into climate processes, including the atmospheric boundary layer, cloud physics and atmospheric chemistry, is also undertaking climate modelling in collaboration with the Bureau of Meteorology to assess the regional impact of the greenhouse effect;
The CSIRO Division of Oceanography which has active programs to observe and analyse the dynamics of the oceans surrounding Australia;
The Antarctic Division of DASETT which undertakes related glaciological research directed to an understanding of climate processes of the Antarctic and adjacent waters of the Southern Ocean;
Several universities which are involved in a range of climate-related projects, both in association with the above organisations and independently.

(c) the Bureau of Meteorology, which comes within my responsibility, has an annual budget of approximately $100 million, of which $1 million is utilised for climate research. This $1 million of course does not include the extensive observing network and data collection and processing systems that are used for routine weather forecasting and climate monitoring, including drought watch. On 6 April 1989 the Prime Minister announced the Government's decision to provide an additional $6.752 million in 1989-90 for the specific purpose of building up Australia's research into the greenhouse effect. Of this, approximately $0.556 million will be allocated to the Bureau of Meteorology to support climate modelling research.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 30 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum did the Minister's Department spend on taxi hire under the Cabcharge system during (a) 1985-86, (b) 1986-87, (c)1987-88, and (d) 1988-89.
(2) When was the Cabcharge system first introduced.
(3) In which cities did most of the expenditure occur.
(4) What controls are applied to ensure that the facility is used for departmental purposes only.
(5) How much did the Minister's Department spend on Commonwealth car hire during (a) 1984-85, (b) 1985-86, (c) 1986-87, (d)1987-88, and (e) 1988-89.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Expenditure on taxi hire under the Cabcharge system was:
(2) The current Cabcharge system has been in use since April 1983. This system was previously used for approximately six months commencing in December 1980.

(3) Cabcharge claims are paid to Aerial Taxis in Canberra. Records of expenditure are not kept State by State but, based on a sample of claims, it is estimated that the majority of expenditure has been in Canberra and Sydney.

(4) To ensure that the facility is used for Departmental purposes only, the issue of Cabcharge credit cards is reviewed on a regular basis and Cabcharge vouchers are signed for on issue to the officer before travel is undertaken. Officers are requested to ensure that the correct details are entered on the vouchers before signing and handing to the taxi driver. Stubs of used vouchers and used credit card dockets are handed in on the officer's return, and resultant claims are examined before payment. Unused vouchers are accounted for.

(5) Present recording systems do not enable the easy separation of expenditure on Commonwealth car hire (with and without driver) from total expenditure on hire of Commonwealth vehicles for passenger and freight movement for the department and those portfolio agencies for which the department provides accounting services. To extract amounts relating solely to the department for Commonwealth car hire either with or without driver over the periods requested would involve the deployment of considerable resources and I am not prepared to authorise the use of those resources.

The total figures given for each of the years includes permanent hire of Commonwealth motor vehicles, hire of vehicles for freight movement and cars with driver for the department and those portfolio agencies for which the Department provides accounting services. The most significant items making up these totals are the expenditure on chauffeur-driven cars and baggage and freight movement for high level visitors under the Guest of Government program. The fluctuations in expenditure between years are largely attributable to variations in the number and category of Guests of Government, especially over the period of the Bicentennial celebrations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 30 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why were the original specifications of the request for tender for the supply of general purpose office chairs for Commonwealth departments and authorities subject to some six amendments.
(2) What was the purpose behind the amendment which shortened the original base stability requirement.
(3) Was Co. Design Pty Ltd, the company which was awarded the contract, the only tender entrant advantaged by the amendment referred to in part (2).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the request for tender for the supply of general purpose office chairs for Commonwealth departments and authorities was amended on six occasions. Three of those amendments related to the chair specification. Details of each of the amendments are as follows:
Amendment No. 1 advised tenderers of changes to the names and telephone numbers of contact officers;
Amendment No. 2 amended the specification by redefining the basis for measuring the base diameter of the chair;
Amendment No. 3 advised tenderers of alterations to proposed contractual conditions regarding ``Inspection'' and ``Price Basis'' requirements. The changes reflected in-house policy revisions;
Amendment No. 4 extended the tender closing date by one week;

Amendment No. 5 advised tenderers of changes to the upholstery and foam specifications. The changes corrected anomalies in the specification and did not disadvantage or favour any tenderers; and, Amendment No. 6 corrected a typographical error appearing in Amendment No. 5.
(2) Amendment No. 2 redefined the basis for measuring the chair's base diameter by altering the specification from:
``the base shall be a minimum of 600mm in diameter through the castor pintle centres'' to:
``the base shall be a minimum of 600mm in diameter''.
I am advised that the amendment was issued to reflect common industry practice following several queries from prospective tenderers.

(3) I am advised that the alteration to base measurement requirements did not advantage Co. Design. I understand that the amendment was prompted by industry response to the specification terminology and that Co. Design could have complied with requirements as originally specified or as amended. I am further advised that of the 28 sample chairs submitted only four failed to meet the base diameter requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 31 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many applications (a) has the Government received for offshore petroleum work program deferments and (b) have been granted, since the collapse of oil prices in 1986.
(2) How many exploration wells have been drilled in the same period.
(3) How many seismic data has been acquired in the three high prospective areas in the Timor Sea released under the cash bonus bidding system in April 1986.
(4) How many Commonwealth offshore permits were in operation at the end of each year since 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) (b) Since January 1986 the Government has received 25 applications to vary the work program conditions of offshore petroleum exploration permits and of these, 24 have been granted. On 13 May 1986 the former Minister for Resources and Energy released a statement on the Government's review of the impact of low oil prices on the petroleum exploration and development industry. In that statement the Minister said that the Government would continue to give sympathetic consideration to proposals from permit holders for deferrals of work program commitments that have merit.
(2) The number of offshore petroleum exploration wells drilled in 1986, 1987 and 1988 were 28, 15 and 32 respectively.
(3) Approximately 5,300 line kilometres of marine seismic surveying has been undertaken in the three cash bid permits in the Timor Sea since they were granted on 4 April 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 1 June 1989:

(2) What was the total expenditure by the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) on nuclear energy research and development in (a) 1986-87, (b) 1987-88 and (c) 1988-89.
(3) Following the replacement of the AAEC with ANSTO, was the research focus shifted from work on the nuclear fuel cycle, in particular power generation.

(4) Is ANSTO conducting any research on the laser enrichment of uranium; if so, (a) what resources are involved and (b) if the research focus has moved from work on the nuclear fuel cycle, why are resources being devoted to research on uranium enrichment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Total expenditure by the AAEC in 1984-85 and 1985-86, by the AAEC and ANSTO in 1986-87, and by ANSTO in 1987-88 and 1988-89 on nuclear energy research and development was (in $million)

(3) As a result of Government decisions prior to 1985, the research focus of the AAEC was shifted away from work on the nuclear fuel cycle. No research work has been undertaken on power generation by nuclear fission since the late 1970s and AAEC programs on uranium enrichment were terminated in 1983. At the time of replacing AAEC with ANSTO, this shift was continued with the reduction of ANSTO involvement in fusion research.

Apart from this small fusion program, the figures reported in (1) and (2) above which are based on figures compiled for the annual Australian Science Statement, represent programs in furtherance of government policy to support international developments in radioactive waste management and IAEA safeguards as well as studies related to environmental protection in uranium mining operations.

(4) Yes. ANSTO has been authorised to undertake a limited program in the field of laser enrichment of uranium so that it is better able to provide authoritative advice to the Government regarding technical aspects of this technology.
(a) In 1988-89, the project involved 0.4 staff years and $21 000. In 1989-90, it is proposed to devote 6 staff years and a budget of $600 000.

(b) ANSTO is devoting limited resources to nuclear fuel cycle activities in order to meet ANSTO's obligations under the ANSTO Act and its Corporate Objective to maintain a core of essential nuclear expertise and national nuclear facilities. This serves to reinforce Australia's international and national strategic interests in nuclear technology and to ensure that Australia has the technical credibility to further its non-proliferation, nuclear safeguards and wider nuclear technology policies and interests.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 15 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the appreciation by the UNICEF Committee of Australia for his support for the global summit for children.
(2) Is he able to say how many world leaders have supported this summit.
(3) Has he examined the possibility of hosting the summit in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I received a letter from the National Director of the UNICEF Committee of Australia on 25 May 1989 expressing appreciation for my support for the global summit.
(2) At 21 June 1989 forty-three national leaders had endorsed the idea of a World-Summit for Children.

(3) The Government has considered the possibility of hosting the summit in Australia but has decided that it would not be possible to do so. In Australia's current budgetary and economic circumstances, I believe that available resources are best directed at the specific protection of the physical and mental well-being of children. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to concern by Australian Service personel and their families over allegations of censorship of mail being sent to and from Namibia?
(2) If so, has he investigated that concern?
(3) What action is the Government able to take in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention has been drawn to concern by Australian Service personnel and their families over allegations of censorship of mail being sent to and from Namibia.

(2) The Department of Defence, in conjunction with Australia Post, has investigated the concern. There is no evidence that letters have been opened or censored. However there is evidence of other mail being opened and items removed. Similar problems are being experienced by all the UN contingents in Namibia. There are strict Namibian customs laws regarding material which is perceived by Namibia authorities to be indecent or obscene. (Experience indicates that Pix, People and Playboy magazines are included in this category). Namibian authorities have the right to deny access to items which, in their opinion, are undesirable imports. In this respect, mail to military personnel is no different from any other mail, and Australia Post understands that the reported removal of magazines is a consequence of normal customs activities.

(3) Wives and relatives of soldiers have been made aware of the regulations governing mail into Namibia. These regulations are available from Australia Post and action has been taken to remind relatives of these problems. I am advised that HQ UNTAG has approached the South African authorities regarding the Namibian customs activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 16 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to allegations made by the Jewish community concerning the denial of basic human rights, in particular restrictions on immigration and freedom of movement, to Jews in Syria?
(2) Is he able to say what the position is in respect of human rights of Jews in Syria?
(3) Has the Australian Government protested to the Syrian Government against human rights abuses in respect of Jews in Syria; if so, in what terms?
(4) What action has the Australian Government taken in international forums to alleviate the situation of Jews in Syria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Reports from our Embassy in Damascus on the position of the Jewish community indicate that Syrian Jews have restrictions placed on them with regard to army service, ownership of property and travel abroad and they are the only confessional group to have a distinguishing mark on their identification cards. The community is subject to close surveillance, though this is, regrettably, a common practice throughout Syria. Jews are ostensibly, and largely in practice, free to engage in most activities in the private sector. The Jewish community is free to practice its religion, and Jewish students are able to attend University.

(3) The Government has been concerned about the human rights situation in Syria for some time. During his visit to Syria in January 1984 the then Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, raised the situation of Syrian Jews during his discussions. Mr Hayden again raised human rights issues with Syrian Foreign Minister Sharaa during his subsequent visit to Damascus in February 1988.

The Australian Embassy in Damascus has made representations to the Syrian authorities regarding individual cases, consistent with Australia's support for internationally accepted standards of human rights and in support of the Amnesty International Parliamentary Group.

(4) The Government has not raised the situation of Jews in Syria in international forums. It is the Government's view that such a course of action is not warranted at the present time and that representations direct to Syrian authorities are more likely to be effective in assisting Jews suffering from discrimination and other forms of human rights abuse.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 June 1989 (Hansard, page 3417) the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) asked me, as Acting Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Acting Treasurer aware that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is now admitting to a 12.65 per cent error rate in relation to the posting out of 1,100,000 tax file number letters in Queensland and Western Australia? Was the Acting Treasurer informed that this error rate was calculated on the numbers of letters-that is, 140,000-actually returned to the Tax Office and that the real error rate is likely to be as high as double that, which means that Australia-wide possibly some 170,000 letters containing tax file numbers remain unaccounted for? In view of the Government's earlier assurances that the tax file number system has integrity, does not this latest information about the ATO's bungled issuing of tax file numbers indicate that the system has been seriously compromised and impaired?
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that information available indicates that of 1,102,959 advices sent to people in Western Australia and Queensland, some 139,570 were returned unclaimed. Therefore there was a return rate of 12.65 per cent. However, the Commissioner does not accept that an error occurred where a letter was returned unclaimed where he had not been advised of the change of address. Errors in the mailout exercise are considered to be those cases where a person had made prior contact with the ATO advising of the change of address and the ATO records were not updated with the result that the advice was mailed to the previous address. Such instances total 213 Australia-wide.

The integrity of the tax file number system has not been seriously compromised. A person knowing another person's tax file number does not allow the first person access to the information behind that number. The ATO has tightened its inquiry policy so that information will not be provided to people simply on the quotation of a tax file number. The ATO will now request further identification that would only be known to the true holder of the number. Where any uncertainty remains as to the person's identity, the information will be mailed to the taxpayer's registered address thereby ensuring that the true owner will receive the information.

Where a person uses another person's tax file number, he or she is in breach of the Taxation Administration Act and subject to fines of up to $10,000 and/or 2 years imprisonment. The ATO can, of course, identify the misuse of tax file numbers.

The secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act have been upgraded to ensure that both taxation officers and people who are not tax officers who have knowledge tax information are subject to strict secrecy provisions which carry hefty penalties.
Where a person feels that his/her tax file number has been seriously compromised the ATO will issue a replacement number.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the Government introduce the Confidential Aviation Incident Reporting (CAIR) Program.
(2) How is the program conducted.
(3) How many reports have been received under the program.
(4) Has the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation prepared a report based on investigations conducted under the CAIR program.
(5) Will she provide a copy of that report to me; if not, why not.
(6) What are the major conclusions in that report.
(7) Does the Government provide an indemnity to pilots providing information under CAIR against action; if not, (a) why not and (b) will the Government provide an indemnity.
(8) Is it proposed to expand the CAIR Program to air traffic controllers and flight service officers; if so, when will this occur.
(9) What consultation will be undertaken prior to the expansion of the program.
(10) What is the attitude of industrial organisations involved in aviation to the CAIR Program.

(11) Has the Government received representations from any industry organisations seeking modifications to the CAIR Program; if so, (a) what modifications were sought, (b) what was the Government's response and (c) if modifications were not agreed to, why were they rejected.
(12) Does the Government propose to centralise flight service centres in capital cities; if so, when will this centralisation take place.
(13) Is the Government confident that the centralisation will not increase the time taken to do a radio flight check; if so, on what grounds is this confidence based.
(14) What is the Government's assessment of concerns expressed by the industry.
(15) Is it possible that what is currently a 2 minute check could in future require 20 minutes.
(16) What is the basis of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) charges and do the current charges recover all, more or less of the costs; if so, what is the percentage of costs recovered.
(17) Has the CAA undertaken to review all operations with the view to increasing efficiency and reducing costs; if not, why not.
(18) If the CAA has reviewed operations, (a) when was the review undertaken, (b) what were the conclusions and (c) what action was taken.
(19) Has the CAA reviewed its office locations with the aim of reducing rents.
(20) Is she able to provide an assurance that there is no overmanning or work practices in the CAA that increase costs or reduce efficiency; if so, what is the basis for this assurance.
(21) If she cannot provide an assurance, why not.
(22) Did the Bosch Report recommend a review on administrative efficiency and costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The CAIR program was introduced in three stages:
(i) On 1 July 1988, reports were invited from flight crew members, that is, pilots and flight engineers;
(ii) On 1 January 1989, CAIR was extended to air traffic services personnel (Air Traffic Controllers and Flight Service Unit Officers);
(iii) On 1 May 1989, the program was further extended to flight attendants, military aviation personnel and ground support personnel such as aircraft maintenance engineers.
(2) The program is conducted as follows:

Aircraft incident reports, (mail and telephone), are received at the CAIR office. Once these reports are de-identified they are entered into CAIR's data base. Written reports to CAIR are shredded and the reporter's I.D. section returned within 3 working days of receipt. The CAIR program is currently administered by two people: (a) a manager who is a senior inspector of air safety and (b) a clerical support member.
(3) In the first eleven months of its operation, the CAIR program received more than 500 usable reports.

(4) To date, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has not prepared a report based on investigations conducted under the CAIR program. However, selected CAIR reports are published regularly in the BASI Journal, providing positive feedback to pilots on the results of their input.

(a) Under present legislation indemnity or immunity from prosecution is not provided. The Department has recently asked the Attorney General's Department to consider whether the provisions and protections of Section 27A of the Air Navigation Act could be extended to material defined in Annex 13 (Aircraft Accident Reporting), paragraph 5.12 (Disclosure of Records) of the International Civil Aviation Organisation International Standards and Recommended Practices.

(b) Amendments to the Air Navigation Act, of course, can only be effected by Parliament. Following advice from the Attorney-General, the Government will consider proposed amendments to the Air Navigation Act.
(8) The CAIR program has already been expended to include all sections of the aviation industry.
(9) Industry representatives, regulatory authorities, unions and associations were consulted prior to implementing each stage of the program.

(10) The Australian Federation of Air Pilots' view is that it cannot recommend the CAIR program to its members until legal protection, as detailed in part 7 of this question, is provided in the Air Navigation Act.
Other unions and associations involved agree with the principles and aims of the CAIR program.
(11) BASI has received representations from industry organisations seeking modification to the CAIR program.
(i) The Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) seeking immunity from prosecution for its members reporting to the program.
(ii) The Aircraft Owners and Pilots' Association of Australia requesting that the CAIR program accept anonymous reports from its members.
(ii) BASI requires that all reports contain identifying information to enable verification or clarification of the report. Anonymous reports are therefore not acceptable.
(ii) Assumptions on the part of BASI, or suspect information accepted into the program, will do nothing to make aviation safer.
(12) The CAA is proposing to centralise flight service units to capital cities. The process of consolidation commenced in 1987 and is expected to be completed by 1994.

(13) The lodging of flight plans by radio and subsequent briefing should take no longer than it now takes for the same activity. This view is based on extensive statistical studies performed as part of the development of the system specification.
(14) Industry has been consulted through representative forums and generally agrees with the measures being taken.
(15) The CAA is confident that planned new facilities and the consolidation process will provide an efficient service that will not cause a 2 minute briefing to become a 20 minute briefing in future.

(16) All the CAA's charges are cost-driven. In the case of airways infrastructure charges, aggregate revenues required are determined by the level of operating costs plus the required level of return on the written-down replacement cost of assets employed. The rate of each charge is set to generate sufficient revenue to cover 100% of the costs of providing the service in question (including return on assets).

In the case of provision of safety regulatory services, charges are set at a proportion of the cost involved of providing the particular service. The remaining unrecovered costs are met by the Government under contract. Government payments for the shortfall are to be phased out over the next six years.

The CAA is required to recover all airways infrastructure costs and, as indicated above, to earn a reasonable rate of return on the Authority's assets. Any profits earned by the Authority will be utilised either toward payment of a reasonable dividend to the Government or toward funding the CAA's capital program.

In the safety regulation area, CAA revenue from industry charges in 1988-89 is estimated at about $4.5 million compared to total costs of about $72.3 million. Accordingly, the majority of costs (94%) are met by the Government.

(17) For services which were previously fully cost recovered, the CAA targeted a 3% (real terms) reduction in charges in the last financial year (1988-89), by holding growth in costs to minimal levels in the face of increased quantity and quality of services required for industry growth.

The pursuit of internal efficiencies to achieve this target was the responsibility of the Board and management, but various guidance was provided by Government, eg through the requirements of the Civil Aviation Act, the Government's previous ``in principle'' endorsement of the Report on Aviation Cost Recovery (the Bosch Report), guidelines applying to performance of Government Business Enterprises, and specific statements concerning the Government's expectations of the CAA.

(18) In addition to the normal and ongoing responsibility of management to capitalise on or create opportunities to increase efficiency, the CAA has instigated a major, service by service, review of functions and costs in the provision of Regulatory and Safety services. The extensive review of Regulatory and Safety services is expected to take about 12 months to complete.

The first report of the Aviation Safety Regulation Review Task Force has been completed. The report's recommendations on improving the legal framework of air safety regulations has been approved in principle by the Government and has been circulated to the aviation industry for comment.

(19) The CAA has recently reviewed its Head and Field Office accommodation requirements. These requirements were assessed against a number of criteria including the need to consolidate disparate staff locations, operational efficiency, cost effectiveness and customer needs.

As the Authority is required to operate on a commercial basis and is required to make a return on assets, an integral part of the review was an assessment of the comparative costs and benefits of different accommodation options (including the cost of retaining existing CAA accommodation). Subsequently the CAA has announced the purchase of National Convention Centre Building No. 6. This was seen as the most cost effective accommodation option.

(20) and (21) As noted in (17), I am advised that the CAA is continually reviewing the various areas of its operations to maximise efficiency. The CAA operates in a dynamic environment, with manning levels and work practices being affected by technological change as well as changing client demands; optimum allocation of resources is therefore a moving target. The CAA advises that it will be constantly pursuing improved efficiency by minimising costs to industry, consistent with its Corporate purpose of ``assisting more people to benefit from safe aviation''.
(22) The Bosch Report recommendations covered a wide range of issues relevant to costs and administrative efficiency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the (a) name, (b) location, including State or Territory, (c) short description and (d) estimated cost of each project funded under the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy.
(2) What consultative arrangements have been established within the program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based upon information supplied by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Aboriginal Development Commission, and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The response is detailed in the tables below.

(2) A National Aboriginal Employment Development Policy Task Force was established to develop the policy from the Miller Report. In 1987, the Task Force was expanded to include three non-agency Aboriginal representatives to aid in the implementation and further policy development. This resulted in the appointment of:

Formal committees have been established between ADC, DAA and DEET at National and State levels to ensure a collective responsiveness to Aboriginal requirements. Negotiations between these agencies and Aboriginal Communities take place on strategies for the delivery of services.
The CDEP scheme was introduced in 1977, in response to requests from Aboriginal communities for an alternative to UB. The Scheme is administered by DAA, and its funding falls into three components
(1) Wages - equivalent to the UB entitlement;
(2) Oncost - 20% of total wages component for administrative costs;
(3) Support- provided for the purchase of one-off capital items and their maintenance.
Each CDEP community has an elected council which decides the work to be done, the rates of pay and generally administers the Scheme.

The AOT program is administered by DAA and provides funds for Aboriginal organisations and community councils which are funded by DAA or the ADC to upgrade the skills of their staff, directors and councillors. The program supports short term, informal and job-related training. In 1988/89 only, the program also includes some Grants for Aboriginal Advancement-General Training projects, which cover a range of Aboriginal community and individual training. This program element, which predates the AEDP, is due to cease on 30 June 1989.
The General Training program supports a range of training for Aboriginal communities and individuals. The program commenced before the AEDP.
Inservice training for Aboriginal Community Workers.
Office of Technical and Further Education

A specific program known as Economic Development Conferences was developed to fund conferences for communities organisations and special interest groups. EDC's will ensure that Aboriginal people can determine employment and economic development needs, opportunities and appropriate plans by providing a forum under the AEDP initiated by and conducted by Aboriginal people.

In the 1988-89 Budget the Government provided funds for AEDP related research and committed a further $1,200,000 for this purpose in 1989-90. Within the Government and the AEDP there is no existing structure for the regular collection of data involving economic research within Aboriginal communities. Therefore to gauge the future direction and target objectives over the next four years Aboriginal research within AEDP programs is essential and of the utmost urgency.
Department of Primary Industries and Energy (Bureau of Rural Resources)-consultancy to research commercial use of wild animal resources by Aboriginal communities
SBFS provides loans assistance or joint loans packages for prospective Aboriginal entrepreneurs.
EDS assist the establishment of community owned and operated business.
MAS provide Aboriginal small businesses with a range of managerial, financial and technical advisory services
DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING
The Government will continue to provide wage subsidy assistance to private and public sector employees for the training and recruitment of unemployed Aboriginal job seekers.
Four major departures from previous approaches are fundamental to the Government's strategy.
(1) to negotiate group training and recruitment packages;
(2) to ensure that training placements are only made when the prospects for recruitment after the training period are high;
(3) to abolish standard on-the-job training subsidies under TAP and make all placements on a Negotiated Fee Basis;
(4) to link the numbers of placements made to the target already identified as that required to achieve equity in Aboriginal employment in the public sector.
The overall emphasis on TAP now is to ensure permanent employment after the training period.
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (ANPWS)

ANPWS was given responsibility for two components of the AEDP. The first component relates to the development of CEP's for Aboriginals in Nature Conservation and the second to the development of Recruitment, Training and Career Development packages relating to mainstream employment.

DEPARTMENT OF PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY

A discrete part of the ADEP funded through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy is an employment and training scheme to increase Aboriginal involvement in Vertebrate Pest and Feral Animal Control and in the game meat industries. Funding for these schemes has been approved, under the Aboriginal Contract Employment Scheme, for an initial period of four years.
The Scheme will provide for increased Aboriginal employment by:
(a) developing Aboriginal employment strategies with State Vertebrate Pest Authorities on the necessary employment infrastructure to ensure that long term Aboriginal employment occurs;

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Community Services and Health: Newspapers and Magazines
